p: The fifteen outbreaks reported to the Jinan CDC from June 2015 to March 2017 occurred mostly in colleges, kindergartens, and schools. Fourteen of the 15 outbreaks were caused by NoVs, including eight by GII infections and six by mixed infection with GII and GI/RoV-A. Seven predominant genotypes (GII.17, GII.3, GII.2, GII.1, GI.6, GI.5 and GI.3) were identified. Since late 2014, non-GII.4 genotypes have been sporadically associated with outbreaks. In the winter of 2014–2015, a novel GII.17 NoV strain (GII.17; Kawasaki 2014) emerged as a major causative agent of gastroenteritis outbreaks in China and Japan [ 17]. During November and December 2016, GII.2 was reported to be the most common genotype in Guangdong and Hong Kong, China [ 28– 29]. During 2014 to 2015, GII.17, GII.3, GI.3, GI.5, and GI.6 were identified in NoV outbreaks in Victoria, Australia, but GII.4 was still the most common genotype detected [ 30]. In our study, no GII.4 strain was identified in the outbreaks. Thus, the emergence of diverse non-GII.4 genotypes played an important role in the outbreaks of AGE in Jinan, China.
